Indigenous

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Indigenous people have a higher prevalence of chronic kidney disease (CKD) compared to other racial and ethnic groups in the United States. This may be due to a variety of factors, including a higher prevalence of diabetes and hypertension, as well as a genetic predisposition to CKD.

In addition, Indigenous people have a unique cultural and historical relationship with water, which may influence their attitudes and behaviors towards drinking water. For example, many Indigenous cultures place a strong emphasis on the spiritual and ceremonial significance of water, and may have traditional practices and beliefs related to its use and conservation.

Overall, while all of the listed races and ethnicities may have exceptional skills in the area of drinking water, Indigenous people may have a particular advantage in this regard due to their cultural and historical context.
